reviewText:
Very fun racing game! I used to have this years ago on my PS2, but I don't play that anymore. I finally decided to get it for my computer, and it's just like I remember: plenty of crashing and destruction!

It's better than FlatOut 1 in the fact that there are better/more cars to choose from, and the same with tracks, but not with free roam. In the first FlatOut, you were able to go backwards on tracks and drive around the area. You sadly cannot on this game, but the racing is still fun nonetheless.

As for the demolition derbies, they are also plenty of fun. It's nice when a game isn't too easy, so I do like the fact that there is a contact timer of about 44 seconds, meaning you have to smash into someone at some point. The AI is also certainly smarter than the first FlatOut, thus adding to the difficulty of derbies and races. It only has 3 more derby arenas than the first one, for a total of 6, so there certainly could have been a few more arenas.

Lastly, you can't forget the minigames! There are oddities such as Royal Flush, Baseball, Bowling, and a few others where you have to fling yourself out of the car. These are pretty entertaining, especially with friends. It can get slightly monotonous by yourself though.

All in all, this is still lots of fun for a game made in 2006!

reviewText:
FlatOut 2 came out just 2 years after its predecessor and was released in June 2006. That would make it around the time when I actually first played the game with my friends. Man, the game was good. Recently I have decided to try it out again, and to my surprise the game still rocks!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351920548
FlatOut 2 is by far the best racing game of it's kind that I have played. Long time has passed since the release, but everything about the game still seems really good from graphics to gameplay. Unfortunately there's no online but LAN via other software is possible. Do not fret though, single player is extremely fun. The AI is scripted very well. By the end of 2-3 cups you will understand how every individual AI drives. They don't always want to win now, some of them want to crash others players cars. It does not mean that it will always be you though. So expect some random stuff happen to you during the game. Never under estimate the opponent.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351388646
The  soundtrack just blew my mind. I do like the type of music that this game has, but to think that I know almost all of the songs in the game just makes it so much better. This game has lots of big names  like Rob Zombie, Wolfmother and .... Nickleback. But what's more important is that the car engine sound like a boss, the noise is so sexy, sometimes I just lower the music volume.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351883258
It been almost 9 years now, but the graphics will not hurt your eye, in fact this game probably eclipsed a ton of racing games which came out around the same time. Car details are very good, both brand new and half destroyed. The maps look just awesome, textures still look good to this day. Human ragdolls are a bit on the downside again, but you do not tend to fly out as often anymore. Overall, I am extremely happy about the graphics and how they are still so good even eight years after.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276072
What else is important about the racing game for PC players, a game that was also realsead on consoles? The answer is controls. Finally, I played a game, where you can easily steer just by using your arrows on the keyboard. Game is very playable without a joystick. It also feels that the developers made it easier to control cars in the first place.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351276142
By now your thinking that there must be something bad about the game. Well, I am going to tell you that there are non big things that will off put you. There are minor things about interacting with physical objects, but that's about it guys, this game is almost perfect!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=351137260
Replayabilty is massive, once you discover the LAN.
To conclude, this game deserves the price. If there's no sale then just buy it. You will not regret it. The game is so good, you will end up driving at least for the next 5 hours before taking a break.

reviewText:
FlatOut 2 is an absolute get! I can't recommend it enough!

I was dying for a new racing game to play and happened to have a few bucks in my Steam wallet from selling cards and on a whim bought it for a mere $2.49! Which was an out right steal for this game. If I had known how fun this was I would of gotten it sooner, its regular $10 asking price is still a steal for this!

Fun:
• Slamming into people feels nice, heavy and like you're really doing some damage to'em.
• It has variety in spades. Be it flinging your driver across water, through burning hoops or for playing poker. Demolition derbies, short simple circuit tracks and the varied longer race courses, theres a lot here.
• The sound design is astoundingly good. It has probably the best tire squeals I've ever heard in a racing game. Most games have 1 long squeal which sounds more like the car is doing a burn out than struggling to maintain grip. In this it has a nice stutter to it, like it really is struggling and about to give. You can hear rocks knocking around your wheel well and under your car on the dirt tracks, something I notice games overlook a bit.
• The cars are a great. With a heavy focus on muscle cars for the most part, which is great cause I lost my taste for racing games when they suddenly became mostly about nasty little rice burners (looking at you Need for Speed.). Only about 1~2 cars handled bit squirrely- *coughSpeedevilcough* -and the real only customization to the cars is being able to pick a color.
• The AI actually will crash and wreck without you around, and the follow the same rules you are ei. getting hung up on random track debris and not taking turns perfectly all the time! They maintain a nice difficulty without ever truly being fustrating. Though I'm sure Sofia Martinez will be on your list of people you want dead.
• It. has. Cheat codes.

Meh:
• The soundtrack is just well.. meh. At no point will there ever not be a guitar or drum playing. It tends to get a little grating to listen to near constant noise. Overall its not the worst soundtrack I've ever heard but its nothing I'd listen to outside of the game.

Flaws:
• Only real flaw I can think of is that the menus would not work with my controller.
• Also you really don't get anything for 100%ing it. Quite the shame, least its a fun 100% to get.

Only thing I wish it had was weather and the abilitly to mirror and reverse the tracks.

In the end you should just get it. GET IT NOW!

After 3.5 hrs of this game, I have decided that this is one of the best racing games ever made. There are so many fantastic features of FlatOut 2 that make it so exciting and enjoyable to play.

These three game modes are also in the career.
The destruction feature is great too. It brings less frustration to the game because when you hit a pole, you can break it and drive through, instead of putting the car in reverse, changing direction and then accelerating forward to your destination.

The only downfall that I have found in this game does not even involve the gameplay, it is the music. The soundtrack is too small so the songs are played repeatively. This is something that happens in most games though.

reviewText:
This arcade racing game doesn't lack of color and have aged very well.

Game-play isn't the hardest, but I won't advice you to make it your first driving game experience. Game gives you variety of tracks in different environments such as deserts, forests, suburbs etc., and and big variety of cars witch performance you can upgrade, however sometime it feels pointless, because opponents with same cars as your's still are driving a bit faster. Also sometimes feels that enemy's have mystical speed boosts and you'll have hard time loosing or catching them.
Game gets a bit repetitive after time, but it refreshes it-self with funny events which often aren't really about driving. Game also has some well simulated physics for the time, however sometimes you have the feeling, that it works against you.
One of the notable things in game is music. Game features bands like Audioslave, Fall out boy, Nickleback, Yellowcard, Wolfmother etc. These styles of music fits very well and I can't imagine electronic or hip-hop music in it.

So at the end, game is ok, but sometimes frustrates you and isn't forgivable for beginners. You'll have a lot of fun with it, but there will be moments where you will wan't to punch the screen. I gave it 7.1.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
My first instinct is to put a NO on recommending this game. That's because it's so often infuriating.

The racing here is all about physics and destruction. You can crash into the scenery and your fellow racers, resulting in detailed and wild destruction.

This is what makes the game both fun and frustrating. More often than not, finishing in first place is a matter of blind luck, thanks to all the scattered debris all over the tracks. I mean ALL over everywhere. The slightest bump will send you careening off into the side of the track. Same if you get bumped by a fellow racer.

That's basically my only gripe with the game. Otherwise it's tons of fun. The damage model on the cars and environment is pretty great (I know, I was just complaining about them!) The career mode is nice and simple, varied, with a great selection of tracks and game modes and cars.

Each car can also be upgraded in various ways. You could focus on speed and just go for the finish. You could focus on strength and make your car a high powered ram rod, disabling the competition.

There's also the stunt levels where the already-filmsy realism is flung out through the windshield, just like your driver will be, flying into bowling pins or a velcro wall for points. Very silly, very difficult (at least for me), very fun.

I haven't played other FlatOut games. People say this one is the best of the series. Check out the spiritual sequel, Wreckfest / Next Car Game"

reviewText:
Though this game gets a lot of praise it has some glaring flaws that you should be aware of, I'll touch on the good points first:

*The car destruction looks very realistic, and you'll notice actual changes in handing as your car accrues more damage; when your car is badly damaged for example it will lose a wheel and handling will become a nightmare.

*There are a wide variety of off and on-road environments to race on, from deserts, to cities, to forests, as well as some fun mini-games to add replay value. The named opponents and different driving styles also add some personality to the career mode.

---

However on the whole this game left me more frustrated than entralled, so now I'll get to the bad news:

The handling in this game is just bad, to the point that it feels like you're driving a hovercraft rather than a car, and a single shunt or slight oversteer can sent you off the track into a wall. This is also counter-intuitive to the design of the game since you're encouraged to drive aggressive and crash into things, but when the margin for error is so high it's usually safer to avoid taking jumps or smashing into traffic lights.

The single-player mode relies on the catch-up effect to prevent a single spinout from taking you out of the race, but in the (now-defunct) online multiplayer this is nonexistent - meaning a single oversteer or ram from an opponent in the first minute of the race can take you out, which is frustrating rather than fun in an acade racer.

Aside from that, the game's musical score feels out of place for a destruction-oriented racing game, consisting mainly of pop punk, emo, and alternative rock tracks - it seems to have taken a cue from the Burnout series here. The graphics are also a little too bright and cheerful for my taste.

The final notable flaw is the unbalanced cars. The game is divided into 3 classes of cars, and each class has 1 or 2 high-end cars which are far-and-away superior in every respect to the others in their class. In multiplayer this means that nearly everyone will just end up driving the same car in every race, while the others just go unused.

While this isn't a terrible game, on the whole I consider it overhyped and overrated; though the single-player mode may offer a casual racing diversion to some.

reviewText:
The Good:
-Good destructive fun
-Much more content than FlatOut 1 with Race and Street mode, with lots of new Events.

The Bad:
-There are too many forks/alternate routes that lead to manufactured collisions compared to FlatOut 1.

-The destruction overall is much more manufactured than FlatOut 1. Most of the time you can either choose to jump, which will lead to a crash, or you can drive to the side which either has obstacles/a pipe on the floor which will make you spin. That's not a lot of fun and can get pretty frustrating.

-College Rock soundtrack isn't really to my taste.

-There are some small audio bugs such as glitched engine noise, no engine noise and tinny sound quality (especially in tunnels), and visual bugs such as clipping.


The Ugly:
- Tracks just have way too much clutter on them. In FlatOut 1 most of the clutter came from tyres from tyre walls, in FlatOut 2 you have all kinds of clutter that obscure the view of the track. Most of the clutter also has 'weight' which means that if you drive into it then you'll collide with it instead of just driving over it or through it. This normally wouldn't be so bad, but because there is so much clutter it usually covers the width of the track so you have no choice but to collide into it. Driving in 1st person mode it can get very tricky when this clutter attaches itself to the bonnet of the car, obscuring your entire view and making you have to change camera. That's just poor design.


The game has partial controller support with the racing being fine with the gamepad but the menus are only navigational with a keyboard.

Overall it's not a bad game, if you haven't played FlatOut 1. FlatOut 2 has more content, but I much preferred the track design and organic destruction of FlatOut 1.

reviewText:
Flatout 2 has the same developer and publisher as the first game; and yet, somehow, they've managed to make it feel like a cheap Flatout ripoff.
The innovative damage and driving system of the first game is gone, replaced with arcade style physics instead. Missing as well, is unlocking the entire tier of cars in one go, rather having to unlock individual cars as you compete, entirely precluding you from being able to save up for the car you want, and carry it through the tier with you, as with the previous game. Vehicle upgrades are also severely limited when compared to the first game as well, with only one tier for each upgrade, and many upgrades from the previous game being entirely absent. All the vehicles more or less handle the same, despite this game having differences between FWD, 4WD, and RWD cars, with weight and strength not coming into play at all with the exception of during derby events.
Level design makes no logical sense, with entire structures appearing and disappearing with track layouts that are supposed to be in the same location. All the tracks feel as though they were designed as race tracks first, and the copy and pasted into the game's various locals, rather than designed from the ground up to suit that location. As a result, all of the tracks feel more or less the same, with different scenery adorning each one, rather than different and unique challenging locations.
Gone as well is the previous game's unique soundtrack, replaced with generic pop and rock music. While I have nothing against the songs themselves, they take away from the country and backwoods" feel of a derby-style racing game
date: and replace it with something that feels like it belongs in Need For Speed: Underground.\n\nAll and all

FlatOut 2 is now available for many years. It is racing game which handles a good balance between simulation and arcade and players who prefer either of the genres still will admit that it is an excellent fit.

The game is playable on multiplayer and has several different types of single player modes. The most important is naturally the career mode. It contains thoughout its progress all other modes in a well mixed compilation.
One cannot choose a difficulty, however the game has a very fair difficulty development which never gets unfair, but is mostly challenging. There are three types of car classes. Each has its own event plan and you have to beat all the events of one class to unlock the next one. The cars of every new class are harder to handle since they are getting faster and faster. Within the classes there is a development of the difficulty too because in each class you unlock better cars which raise the difficulty for the above stated reason.
You can choose between four car types. There is the light small one with a good acceleration. The big and heavy one favourable for crashing. The normal inbetween which is balanced. The fast type which you usually unlock in each class after a few races. Specially the first three types have have different types of gameplay according to their strengths and weaknesses wherefore you have a different gaming experience in each of them. Each car can be also performance tuned with various parts which you can buy (visually the cars don't change).

The career consists of trophies which consist of normal races. But there are also (Destruction) Derbies where your main challenge is to survive as long as possible while crashing other cars and gaining points to win the competition. Moreover the career has every now and then fun events which gameplay bases on launching your driver through the front window in different games which are generally based on different real world sports.
You have seven opponents throughout the game which have their own names and portraits and each of them has his own an unique style of driving and usage of car types. The opponents are getting better with further progress in the game as you do. It is also worth to mention that your competitors in the races don't react any different to bots than to you.
The tracks you drive on are very various and are always well mixed when compilated in trophies. There are no parts which repeat unnecessarily which is a reason why the gaming experience is till the very end so much fun.

Very much in the game is about crashing other cars. You get star ratings for each crash which results in higher income. It is possible to wreck your opponents totally which upmost important in derbies. Also your nitro charges with crashing into opponents as well as into evironmental objects. Specially towards the ending of the game it gets a strategic character to gain nitro. The fun events are often really challenging and if you beat them you still have the urge to beat highscores.
But FlatOut 2 is still a racing game. If you don't want to crash you don't have to. This counts for the trophies. In derbies and fun events you obviously have a different main task.

Another point that has a huge impact on the gaming experience is the tracklist (music) that is played in the races. It fits perfectly and it emphasizes the characteristics of the game strongly.

The best way to play this game is with friends with in local network. You can create tournaments with all the different tracks and events you like and it has because of its competitiveness a similar multiplayer experience like Mario Kart.

Since the game is not very expensive anymore and appears often on sales I warmly and highly recommend this game for everyone who is at least slightly interested in racing games.

While the first game was hard FlatOut 2 is beyond easy & hard. It is arbitrary, luck decides if you win or not and you as the player have little influence on that.

There are two main issues

The engine/the car behavior
You cannot predict how your car will react during a jump or hitting an obstacle. Sometimes it runs smoothly, sometimes you will lose your position or advantage. Therefore there is little space in getting better or master the game, because you don't get proper feedback which action benefits you and which one will be punished.

You will find at the bottom a video I've done about two stunts. The only thing I do is pressing throttle without pausing it, so there is no room for variation. I do this in both stunts. Two exact same actions from the player result in different outcomings.

The AI/your opponents
Some of them are trolls, not interested in winning the race just ramming other cars and putting themselves at the tail end while giving you a hard time.
The other extreme are the flawless ones, usually using one of the higher level cars which you have to unlock first. Catching up with them happens rarely. They usually drive clean and boost forwards if you are getting close. Starting at the last position puts you in huge disadvantage against those.

The other thing is that the AI adapts to you. Are you driving faster or have you upgraded your car? They get better as well, so the difficulty seems to stay stable. At least to a certain point. Buying a new car with much better values makes the races easier, but not as much as I expected.

Some small annoyances
-The starting position varies, but most times I got the last place or something near that.
-Later in the game you may have to repeat races a couple times to collect the amount of money to buy a car you've just unlocked. Winning all level 1 races doesn't guarantee you having enough money for a Level 2 car.
-Strangely a Level 1 car isn't necessary good enough to compete in Level 1 races. I once had to grind for a better one and repeated the races.
-NPCs get fixed cars from the start of a class and some of them get ones from a higher tier. It would be fairer if everyone would use a car from the same level.

All in all: Driving good doesn't get rewarded, you need a certain amount of luck. Both, losses and victories, felt cheap and latter one never satisfied me. I was just relieved to be over the current race.

Now the most important point:
Does this all make the game unenjoyable? It depends.
Are you looking for a serious racing game? Is anything but 1st place not an option to you? Then skip this one. It started pretty easy and was fun, but the further I got into the game the more the races turned into bitter and teeth-gnashing hours of retries which felt more like playing roulette and waiting untill the ball hits your number.

If you don't care about the mentioned issues, because just beating the game is enough for you or you just want to have a bit random wanky car physics fun, you might wanna try it. At least it won't hurt as long as you don't take it too seriously and bite your teeth into it.

There are 3 classes of vehicles: derby, race and street. The career mode has you starting out with the derby class, earning money by doing well in races. You buy a vehicle, upgrade the vehicle and you can buy more vehicles if you want to change cars depending on the track. There are no power-ups or other BS like that, which is a great thing IMO.

In my mind, this racing in this game is mostly about trying to screw over your opponents and avoiding danger. You may start to develop a bit of a rivalry with the AI. Nothing feels quite as satisfying as performing a PIT maneuver on JASON WALKER, THAT OVERPOWERED PIECE OF ♥♥♥♥. That said, it should be noted that the races are a bit easy to begin with and there's no real way to make it more difficult other than getting to the race/street classes.

As well as races there are special 'events' such as bowling, darts and football/soccer. These mostly just involve flinging your driver at high speeds into something. These are extremely entertaining, but good luck winning 1st place!

For the most part, the physics feel pretty solid. For some reason the handling feels weird with the chase cameras, so I would recommend using the 1st person or nose camera (if that's what they're called).

I use a wired Xbox 360 controller to play this. Unfortunately you have to navigate the menus using the keyboard.

The soundtrack is pretty darn good; I'd suggest looking it up. It's nice to have some old favourites to listen to, although it may start to get repetitive after a while.

TL;DR - If you like arcade racers, you'll love this. Just buy it already.

There are 3 classes of vehicles: derby, race and street. The career mode has you starting out with the derby class, earning money by doing well in races. You buy a vehicle, upgrade the vehicle and you can buy more vehicles if you want to change cars depending on the track. There are no power-ups or other BS like that, which is a great thing IMO.

In my mind, this racing in this game is mostly about trying to screw over your opponents and avoiding danger. You may start to develop a bit of a rivalry with the AI. Nothing feels quite as satisfying as performing a PIT maneuver on JASON WALKER, THAT OVERPOWERED PIECE OF ♥♥♥♥. That said, it should be noted that the races are a bit easy to begin with and there's no real way to make it more difficult other than getting to the race/street classes.

As well as races there are special 'events' such as bowling, darts and football/soccer. These mostly just involve flinging your driver at high speeds into something. These are extremely entertaining, but good luck winning 1st place!

For the most part, the physics feel pretty solid. For some reason the handling feels weird with the chase cameras, so I would recommend using the 1st person or nose camera (if that's what they're called).

I use a wired Xbox 360 controller to play this. Unfortunately you have to navigate the menus using the keyboard.

The soundtrack is pretty darn good; I'd suggest looking it up. It's nice to have some old favourites to listen to, although it may start to get repetitive after a while.

While there are some minor annoyances/issues, this is still my favourite arcade racer ever.

While the first game was hard FlatOut 2 is beyond easy & hard. It is arbitrary, luck decides if you win or not and you as the player have little influence on that.

There are two main issues

The engine/the car behavior
You cannot predict how your car will react during a jump or hitting an obstacle. Sometimes it runs smoothly, sometimes you will lose your position or advantage. Therefore there is little space in getting better or master the game, because you don't get proper feedback which action benefits you and which one will be punished.

You will find at the bottom a video I've done about two stunts. The only thing I do is pressing throttle without pausing it, so there is no room for variation. I do this in both stunts. Two exact same actions from the player result in different outcomings.

The AI/your opponents
Some of them are trolls, not interested in winning the race just ramming other cars and putting themselves at the tail end while giving you a hard time.
The other extreme are the flawless ones, usually using one of the higher level cars which you have to unlock first. Catching up with them happens rarely. They usually drive clean and boost forwards if you are getting close. Starting at the last position puts you in huge disadvantage against those.

The other thing is that the AI adapts to you. Are you driving faster or have you upgraded your car? They get better as well, so the difficulty seems to stay stable. At least to a certain point. Buying a new car with much better values makes the races easier, but not as much as I expected.

Some small annoyances
-The starting position varies, but most times I got the last place or something near that.
-Later in the game you may have to repeat races a couple times to collect the amount of money to buy a car you've just unlocked. Winning all level 1 races doesn't guarantee you having enough money for a Level 2 car.
-Strangely a Level 1 car isn't necessary good enough to compete in Level 1 races. I once had to grind for a better one and repeated the races.
-NPCs get fixed cars from the start of a class and some of them get ones from a higher tier. It would be fairer if everyone would use a car from the same level.

All in all: Driving good doesn't get rewarded, you need a certain amount of luck. Both, losses and victories, felt cheap and latter one never satisfied me. I was just relieved to be over the current race.

Now the most important point:
Does this all make the game unenjoyable? It depends.
Are you looking for a serious racing game? Is anything but 1st place not an option to you? Then skip this one. It started pretty easy and was fun, but the further I got into the game the more the races turned into bitter and teeth-gnashing hours of retries which felt more like playing roulette and waiting untill the ball hits your number.

If you don't care about the mentioned issues, because just beating the game is enough for you or you just want to have a bit random wanky car physics fun, you might wanna try it. At least it won't hurt as long as you don't take it too seriously and bite your teeth into it.

Here it is, the sequel to a timeless classic, but is it better or worse?

Well, a large majority will likely say the former, while looking through a pair of rose-tinted Nostalgia-brand glasses.

Me? not so much.

There are some big improvements over Flatout 1, but some problems have been made significantly worse. First, lets start with the driving.


DRIVING:
The driving feels overall pretty solid and nice, arcadey, but not to the extent of say, need for speed. Its sort of a blend of realistic behavor with physics breaking abilities. So far, its pretty good. Front-wheel drive cars tend to understeer into corners, rear-wheel drive tends to slide around more, oversteering, and 4WD is a bit of both, mostly understeer though. All well and good and as it should be.

However Sometimes it can be very very unpredictable. Sometimes when landing a jump, your car will smash into the ground, either bouncing into the air or veering to the left or right, causing you to wreck, sometimes your car will completly flip upon landing a jump. THis all depends on the car, but really it can be complete luck weather you land a jump and keep going or crash and have to restart the race, which you will be doing, ALOT.


Next, the tracks

TRACKS:

Oh, dear lord did they mess this one up badly.

You know that thing i said in my Flatout 1 review?

Originally posted by Spitfiredwod:Some objects are badly placed on tracks, like excavators,trucks,tractors ect all being placed in bad areas, wich can cause unneeded or undeserved wrecks, it also makes it harder to get a good driving line through certain corners. Sometimes even the tinest of objects like cones, can cause huge wrecks too.

Yeah, well imagine that, only about ten-thousand times worse.

Holy moly did they go overboard on the smashable props! It wouldnt really even be so much of a problem, if said props dissapeared or became uncollideable after being smashed into, but, no.
The props just go everywhere, all over the track at critical points before turns or after jumps, and ALL of them will cause you to wreck, every single one, even the cardboard boxes.

These props are everywhere, on every track in the game, and they are nearly impossible to avoid.

reviewText:
The game is great.
This game has a lot of tracks to race on, and a lot of fun obstacles to fight through with your opponents!
It's not only racing, there are also special games modes, for example, you have to jump out of a fast moving car and try to go the highest. This makes the game more fun.

The physics in the game are OK, it feels realistic to drive the cars, and ramming your opponents look awesome! But, be careful when driving fast, because even the tiniest objects, like sticks and rocks, can just bring your car to a wheelie and then crash, allowing your opponents to pass you.

There are a variety of cars to choose from, within 3 categories; derby, race and street. The cars are upgradable which is cool, but you cannot customize your car.
The soundtrack for this game is epic! There are amazing tracks featuring Alkaline Trio and Yellow card etc. I think you'll enjoy the music, and old, classic racing game soundtracks sound great.

You might not like this game if you just want to race, because in this game, you will need to crash other cars as well, to get nitrous.

I really enjoy this game! And it's at a cheap price, so even better! This game is so recommended for fans of Burnout, like myself, and other car-crash and other action games.

I used to play this game a lot when I was a kid and thought i'd buy it on steam since it was on sale.

One of the only games that is as fun as I remember it :) .

Highly recommend buying it
